text: it was just the fourth appearance by a prime minister at a royal commission , and this is how it went down : former pm julia gillard had admitted that she would do the whole thing differently if she could go in a time machine back to when she gave legal advice to her then-boyfriend , bruce wilson , on establishing a union slush fund .

but the former pm sought to distance herself from the slush fund wilson created , the australian workers union workplace reform association , saying she only advised on setting it up , and knew nothing about its banking arrangements , its po box , its day-to-day operations , or an advertisement placed in the west australian newspaper in 1992 advertising its existence .
wilson forced gillard to begin renovating her home in 1993 by demolishing her bathroom while she was away on holidays .
gillard said she had been talking about renovating the bathroom for months .
bruce wilson obviously thought i should get on with it and created circumstances where i had to get on with it , she said .
gillard has denied allegations by previous witnesses , athol james , wayne hems and ralph blewitt , that her renovations were funded by wilson using money from the union slush fund .
in 1995 , i took steps to satisfy myself that looking at the amount of work that had been performed on my home , that i had paid for it all .
that i had documents , receipts , invoices , that showed that i 'd paid for it all , gillard said .
gillard has defended not creating a legal file for the advice she gave wilson and blewitt , leading to the creation of a union slush fund .
gillard said that she often did pro-bono work for unions , andit was always a judgement call about whether or not one would open a file for work that you were not going to charge a fee .

a former hsu official has withdrawn a statement he gave in 2012 alleging that former pm julia gillard advised that a proposed union election fund should be given the ostensible purpose of promoting occupational health and safety .
rob elliot said his false statement had fundamentally shaken his faith in his own memory .
to say that i 'm embarrassed about it does n't begin to describe it , he said .

text: as galbally wraps up his questioning of gillard , commisioner heydon calls time on the former prime minister 's appearance in the witness box .
thanks for sticking with us on a day that would have proved a nail-biter for west australian corporations law buffs , but may have proved a little dry for the rest of us .
we 'll have a summary up soon and a full report and analysis from guardian australia political editor , lenore taylor .
blewitt 's brief is asking the same questions of gillard that were asked this morning by stoljar , earning the ire of commissioner heydon ( and the groans of many in the media room ) .
mr galbally , we are rephrasing almost word for word evidence given this morning .
again you may like to try and get the witness to change her evidence , but it is trespassing on well-trodden ground , the commissioner says .

documents.title: stoljar 's questioning ends
text: with that , counsel assisting jeremy stoljar sc has finished his questioning of the former prime minister .
on his feet to begin the cross-examination is bob galbally sc , barrister for ralph blewitt .
gillard is now being questioned about the evidence from former hsu official , robert elliot , that the former pm advised him in the early 90s about setting up a slush fund .
you might remember that this morning elliot withdrew parts of his evidence - that gillard suggested the slush fund should be given the ostensible purpose of promoting occupational health and safety .
but he maintains the discussion about the fund occurred .
gillard disagrees : the event referred to did not happen
we 've fast forwarded to 1995 now , when the alleged wrongdoing involving wilson , blewitt and the workplace reform association was beginning to be known .
gillard says that wilson approached her in her capacity as a solicitor to discuss the matters , but she felt uncomfortable and referred him to another lawyer .
shortly after , gillard says she nixed the relationship .

subsequent to these events i had a discussion with mr wilson where he was evasive and i formed the view that i had not been fully in the about the nature of his conduct and i took steps to end our relationship .

stoljar is now putting to gillard the evidence of wayne hems , a former awu staffer , who claimed to have visited gillard 's home and seen bill telikostoglou ( aka bill the greek ) handing over an envelop of cash to people working at the house .
i 'm not in a position to deny witness evidence about an event that i was not at , gillard says .
but i can say this : in accordance with our earlier discussion , i checked my expenditure in relation to my renovations and satisfied myself that i paid for it in full .

she also says that hems ' statement fails to accurately describe her home , and appears to suggest that several tradespeople working on the house at once - but in fact the jobs on the house were done separately .
he 's got the nature of the property wrong , he 's got the layout wrong , he has the combination of the tradespeople wrong , she says .
now some big questions , based on glassworker athol james ' evidence to the commission that gillard told him repeatedly that wilson would be paying him for his work .
you told him on a number of occasions that mr wilson was paying for the renovations ?
stoljar asks .
that 's completely untrue , gillard replies .
because mr wilson was in fact paying for the renovations .
it 's just not true mr stoljar .
just not true .
wilson has admitted to using $ 8,000 from the awu-wra to purchase computers , a printer , a fax machine and answering machine in november 1993 .
he 's also admitted to splashing cash around on other big purchases at the time .
you were in a relationship with [ wilson ] at the time .
did you notice whether or not during 1993 he had significant amounts of cash on him , stoljar asks .
i never saw mr wilson with significant amounts of cash , gillard replies .
gillard : i got renovations done at my home .
and i paid for them .
it became controversial in 1995 .
i took steps to check .

the former pm has also said she takes no issue with justice murphy 's testimony yesterday , that in 1995 , gillard blamed enemies within the labor party for creating the rumours that her renovations had been paid for by slush fund money .
interestingly , gillard was less certain that wilson had n't paid for any part of the renovations in her 1995 exit interview with slater & gordon .

i ca n't categorically rule out that something at my house did n't get paid for by the association or something at my house i just - i do n't feel confident saying that i can categorically rule it out , she said at the time .
stoljar is now trying to establish whether it was possible that wilson made cash payments to tradesmen working on gillard 's home without her knowledge .
the position is that either mr wilson or mr [ jim ] collins on his behalf may have paid some of the tradesmen who were coming in and out and you would n't have known anything about it , he asks .
in 1995 , i took steps to satisfy myself tjay looking at the amount of work that had been performed on my home , that i had paid for it all .
that i had documents , receipts , invoices , that showed that i 'd paid for it all , gillard says .
stoljar : were you annoyed that mr wilson had smashed up your bathroom ?
gillard : it was n't my preference , no .
before invoice-gate really explodes , commissioner heydon intervenes , pointing out that gillard has indeed made reference to an invoice in the past .
the questioning moves on .
gillard has just said that she received invoices from the various tradesmen she had engaged to work on her home , which has stirred quite a reaction from stoljar .
he says that gillard has been answering questions on these renovation for many years ( i most certainly have , mr stoljar ) and has never brought up receiving any invoices - only receipts .
athol james has now been raised .
he 's a glassworker who was contracted to carry out work on gillard 's home , and who earlier told the commission that he saw wilson twice give gillard wads of cash .
she said that bruce wilson was paying for the work onsite , but she would get the money from him and give me her cheque ¦ on two occasions , i saw him hand over a wad of notes , james said .
wilson has told the commission this was a lie .
stoljar is asking whether gillard did any budgeting or costing on how she would fund her renovations .
between doing thing like extending my mortgage and relying on my salary , i was confident that i was able to finance them , gillard says .

documents.title: royal commission resumes
text: former pm gillard has returned to the witness box , where she 's facing questions over renovations she made on her home in 1993 - allegedly funded by money from the union slush fund .

gillard has just told the commission that she went to queensland for a holiday , and that while she was away , her then-boyfriend bruce wilson commenced with a group of friends demolishing the bathroom .
gillard had apparently been talking about renovating the bathroom for months .
bruce wilson obviously thought i should get on with it and created circumstances where i had to get on with it , she said .
by the time i came back the bathroom had been demolished so i had no option but to get the rest of the renovations done .
the commission had adjourned for lunch , set to resume about 2pm .

here 's the day so far : a former hsu official has withdrawn a statement he gave in 2012 alleging that former pm julia gillard advised that a proposed union election fund should be given the ostensible purpose of promoting occupational health and safety .
rob elliot said his false statement had fundamentally shaken his faith in his own memory .
to say that i 'm embarrassed about it does n't begin to describe it , he said .

gillard has defended not creating a legal file for the advice she gave her ex-boyfriend , former awu official bruce wilson , and his associate ralph blewitt , leading to the creation of a union slush fund .
gillard said that she often did pro-bono work for unions , and it was always a judgement call about whether or not one would open a file for work that you were not going to charge a fee .

the former pm has sought to distance herself from the slush fund wilson created , the australian workers union workplace reform association , saying she only advised on setting it up , and knew nothing about its banking arrangements , its po box , its day-to-day operations , or an advertisement placed in the west australian in 1992 advertising its existence .
stoljar is now trying to figure out just how deeply involved gillard was in the purchase of the fitzroy investment property .
the former pm says that she never did conveyancing work , leaving it to paralegals at the firm .
but stoljar is leading evidence that gillard intervened at points in the process , including in chasing blewitt for a certificate of currency .
gillard concedes that she chased up commonwealth bank , or chased up ralph to chase up the commonwealth bank , i do n't know which , but maintains her overall involvement was marginal .

gillard is explaining that she prepared a power of attorney for ralph blewitt so that bruce wilson could attend the auction for the fitzroy investment property and purchase it in blewitt 's name .
stoljar is pushing for more details of the day of the auction - in particular , how the deposit on the home was paid .
did [ wilson ] have a cheque from mr blewitt ?
stoljar asks .
i do n't know , gillard replies .
well how was the deposit paid ?
i do n't have any recollection from the time about how the deposit was paid , gillard says firmly .
we 're now moving onto the purchase by wilson of a property at 85 kerr st in the inner-melbourne suburb of fitzroy - allegedly with funds from the awu-wra .
stoljar begins by asking whether gillard and wilson , by then in a relationship , ever discussed the slush fund .
from time to time , we discussed matters at work .
whether you had a particularly good day , if you had a particularly bad day .
but no , we did not discuss the association , she says .
whilst this matter has come to assume a great deal of significance in the years since , at the time of these events and my provision of advice , it had no particular significance .
in terms of a busy legal practice , it did not stand out .
stoljar is now focusing on the invoices issued by the awu workplace reform association to the construction company , thiess .
thiess paid a total of $ 380,000 to the slush fund , with both blewitt and wilson admitting that the company received nothing in return .
gillard is denying having advised either man on setting up a po box for the slush fund , nor the bank account into which thiess ' money was paid .

stoljar : do you accept now that it would have been appropriate for you to go to the awu and slater & gordon and gordon 's client and say look , has someone given authorisation for the use of your name in respect of this association ?
gillard : none of us get to go in a time machine and go backwards .
obviously , if one got to do the whole thing differently given what i know that i did not know at the time

stoljar is asking whether gillard ever thought it was misleading for the slush fund to be named the australian workers union workplace reform association when it had no formal association with the awu .
stoljar : did it cause you concern , the name of the union in the name of the association it 's misleading is n't it ?
gillard : in what sense ?
stoljar : in the sense that the association is a part of or authorised by the awu .

gillard : there was nothing in any of this back at the time which cause me to conclude in any way that the name of the association or anything else about the association would be used to mislead people .
gillard is saying that she set up the alleged slush fund and gave general advice on how it should operate , but had no direct involvement in the entity beyond that .

i would have explained that an incorporated association has members , that there 's a minimum number of members , that you have to have a committee of management , and having explained those things , would have left it to mr blewitt and mr wilson to work out how they wanted the association to work , she says .

text: we 're off again after a short adjournment , with counsel assisting stoljar still focusing on the rules of the awu workplace reform association , which gillard drafted in 1992 .
not a huge amount of new material so far in gillard 's testimony , as andrew casey points out .

until now jg response have basically been what she has said 100s of times b4 at various media conferences
commissioner heydon has called a short break .
we 're due to resume in about 15 minutes .
stoljar is still trying to establish who drafted the advertisement that appeared in wa local papers in 1992 , announcing the proposed creation of the awu workplace reform association .

commissioner john heydon has suggested the stilted formal language in the advertisement could be the result of someone using a legal template - rather than evidence that a lawyer , most probably gillard , was involved .
that may well be , commissioner , stoljar says .
gillard 's silk , neil clelland sc , points out that bruce wilson has testified that it was he who drafted the advertisement .
michael safi ( @ safimichael ) some key pars from gillard 's statement , currently being drawn out on the stand

deep in the minutiae of west australian corporation law it says that any incorporated entity must first be advertised in a local newspaper to allow any objectors to speak out or forever hold their peace .

such an advertisement did appear for the alleged awu slush fund , claiming that the new incorporated entity was being formed for promoting and encouraging workplace reform for workers performing construction and maintenance work .
stoljar notes that it appears to be cast in a legal flavour , implying that gillard drafted a raison d'etre for the slush fund that she knew to be false .
is it likely that you gave advice as to the content of the advertisement ?
he asks .
mr stoljar , i do n't recall giving any advice about the advertisement , gillard says .

we 're now hearing about the meeting - most likely held in melbourne , gillard says - where the former pm met with blewitt and wilson in order to discuss the associated entity that would become the infamous awu workplace reform association .
gillard is being asked whether she exercised due care and skill in her advice to the two union officials .
i was trying to do my best , mr stoljar , yes , she said .
i was obviously trying to give them the benefit of my professional expertise .
lenore taylor ( @ lenoretaylor ) jg says she had done much more substantial legal work for trade unions than the awu workplace reform association for free
gillard is explaining why she never set up a legal file recording the work she had done for wilson in setting up the alleged awu slush fund .
it was always a judgement call about whether or not one would open a file for work that you were not going to charge a fee .
there were various arrangements for doing that .

you would keep file notes and they may be put on your personal file , so i had a file in the filing cabinet called jeg general for our trade union clients , she says , detailing other ways to record minor work done without fee for trade unions .
but this was substantial job , you accept that ?
stoljar asks .
no , i do n't , gillard replies .
you do n't accept that ?
no , this would have been a job that took me in total , oh i do n't recall specifically , but i would have said in the order of three , four , five hours ' work at most , she says .

gillard is now being questioned about her exit interview when she left slater and gordon in 2005 , in which she appears to have acknowledged the existence of an account linked to the awu workplace reform association .
i had no knowledge at that time or knowledge at any time about the banking arrangements of the workplace reform association , she says .
stoljar keeps pressing : the fact is that you knew that it had set up an account and was operating an account under the same name as the association .
mr stoljar , i 'm not sure i can take it further for you than i have , gillard says .
from my colleague daniel hurst : the labor leader , bill shorten , was asked at a media conference in melbourne a short time ago about julia gillard 's appearance in the witness stand .
shorten said he had made clear that he would not be providing a running commentary on the tony abbott royal commission into trade unions .
what i do know is that julia gillard has constantly and repeatedly denied the allegations made against her of wrongdoing .
in her statement , gillard said that it was common practice within unions for union officials to establish election funds which were used to finance election campaigns .
she was asked for advice on the creation of such a fund and gave it .
mr wilson raised with me wanting to have a fund in wa that would support him and his team and their re-election in wa , gillard says .
stoljar : when did you first hear about the workplace reform association ?
gillard : in 1992 , i received instructions from mr wilson about providing legal advice on the incorporation of an association .

stoljar is establishing that gillard borrowed the overwhelming bulk of the money she used to pay for her abbotsford property in 1991 , perhaps building to questions about how she paid for renovations on the property - renovations that ralph blewitt and other witnesses have suggested were partly paid for by money from bruce wilson 's awu slush fund .
can you tell the commission your current occupation ?
counsel assisting the inquiry , jeremy stoljar sc , asks .
um , there 's a list , the former pm says , rattling off seven or eight positions , including a fellowship at the brookings institution .

text: your name is julia eileen gillard ?
yes it is .
and we 're off .
as we wait for the former pm to front the royal commission , cast your eye over lenore taylor 's analysis on tuesday of the allegations gillard can expect to face .

this is key : but the questions to be put to gillard now focus on two sharp points : what she knew about the operations of a slush fund set up by her boyfriend in the early 1990s , australian workers ' union official bruce morton wilson including its use to buy a house ; and whether any money from the fund was used in a series of somewhat bungled renovations on a different melbourne house that gillard owned at the time .

julia gillard is the next witness - she 'll be in the stand after a five minute recess .
interestingly , we 're told by gillard 's silk that the former prime minister disputes that she raised the prospect of the fundraising account with darveniza and elliot .
with that , darveniza is also excused from the stand .

to recap ; both elliot and darveniza have said this morning that gillard raised the question of setting up the fundraising account in the early 1990s , but denied - contra elliot 's statement in 2012 - that the former prime minister told them that the ostensible purpose of the account should be to promote occupational health and safety .
michael safi ( @ safimichael ) here 's what rob elliot said in his 2012 statement , that he now says was false # turc @ twitterid

darveniza is testifying that gillard advised both her and her husband , rob elliot , on setting up a fundraising entity , but says she does not recall that gillard suggested the fund be established ostensibly for the purpose of raising funds for health and safety .
elliot has not been excused from the stand , and his partner , victorian state labor senator kaye darveniza , has been called .

in 2012 , elliot gave a statement that in the early 1990s , former prime minister julia gillard , then a lawyer with slater and gordon , offered to do the legal work to establish a fundraising entity outside of the union to raise funds for the re-election in the hsu of the officers in that entity .
the ostensible purpose of the entity was to promote occupational health and safety , according to elliot 's statement two years ago .

but elliot is now repudiating the statement , saying his memory has been agitated by discussions in the past few weeks that lead him to believe that he has conflated other things at the time of making the statement to come up with a false scenario .
it was decided that no entity be established , no entity was established , elliot says .
he says that the statement has fundamentally shaken his faith in his own memory .
to say that i 'm embarrassed about it does n't begin to describe it , he says .

we 're hearing from robert elliot , a former health services union official , who gave a statement two years ago that in the late 1980s , julia gillard advised him and other hsu officials to establish a fundraising entity that could be used for union elections .
that 's all we know about gillard 's alleged advice so far .
interestingly though , elliot now says that he no longer believes key elements of his statement .

documents.title: hearing begins with former hsu official robert elliot
text: welcome to our live coverage of the long-awaited appearance by the former prime minister , julia gillard , at the royal commission into trade union corruption .

this current phase of the inquiry focuses on the australian workers union , the victorian and west australian branches of which were headed up at the time by gillard 's then-boyfriend , bruce wilson .

gillard had admitted to helping wilson prepare the paperwork to establish an alleged union slush fund , the awu workplace reform association , which was maintained by wilson and another awu official , ralph blewitt .
wilson is alleged to have used around $ 90,000 from the slush fund to purchase a house in inner-city melbourne in 1993 , a charge he denies .

other money from the slush fund was also allegedly used to pay for a series of bungled renovations on a home gillard owned in abbotsford , in melbourne 's inner-east - though concrete evidence of this claim is yet to be produced .
the former prime minister has repeatedly denied any knowledge of what wilson is alleged to have done , and says no illegal money was used to fund her renovations .
two witnesses were added to the list early this morning to appear before gillard fronts the commission .
the first is robert elliott , a former official with the health services union .
his testimony has just begun .
